annotation.text: How we doing, furious flowers?
Y'all like, "Oh, we're too tired to clap."
(Laughs)
We are going to go ahead and get our Black
Universe 4 reading started. (Audience Chattering)
I'm so excited to have this final lineup of,(...) I don't know, supernovas in our
Black Poetry constellation. I don't know, I'm pushing that metaphor all the way,
y'all. But we are going to do the do. We have done it three times, so I think we
know how it goes. Our poets are going to introduce each other.
We are going to get our minds repeatedly blown, and we will clap for it like we,
you know, let them know the love.(...) And our
first poet is Terrence Hayes.(...) (Audience Cheering)
All right, y'all. (Audience Laughing) I heard you had more than one of those socks.
Okay, I got one thing really to read y'all that I've been working on for you, but
with all this deer stuff, I feel like I should throw in my little,
my deer poem from one of these books.
I think it's, can I say it's for Roger? I'm gonna say it's for Roger.
How to be Drawn is the book he was in. The Deer.
I'm so glad to be here. I knew I was gonna forget to do that. Lauren,(...) I love
y'all. Y'all just make it home, you know? You make it home.
And as soon as I knew I was coming, I started thinking about this moment of what I
would do for my family. So that's what I've been
working on. But here, let's do this deer thing first.
Outside Pataskala, I saw the deer with the soft white belly, the deer with two eyes
as blind as holes.(...) I saw it leap from a bush beside the highway as if a moment
before it leapt, it had been a bush beside the highway. And saw how if I wished it,
I could be the deer. A creature boning as a branch in spring. And when I closed my
eyes, I found the scent of muscadine. The berry my mother plucked Sundays from the
roadside where fumes toughened its speckled skin and seeds
slept suspended in mucus thick as the sleep of an embryo.
It is the ugliest berry along the road. But chewed, it reminded me of speed. And I
saw when I was the deer that I didn't have to be a deer. I could become a machine
with the woman inside it, moving at a speed that leaves a stain on the breeze and
on the muscadine's flesh, which is almost meat, the sweet pulp a muscadine leaves
when it's crushed in the teeth of a deer or a mother for that matter, or her child
waiting with something like shame to be fed a berry uglier than shame.(...) Though
it is not like this for the deer, it is not shame because the deer is not human. It
is only almost human when it looks on the road and leaps covering at least 30 feet
in a blink. The deer I cannot be. The dumb deer, dumb and foolish enough to ignore
anything that runs but is not alive. A trafficking machine filled with a distracted
mind and body deadly and durable enough to deconstruct the
deer when it leaps, I'm telling you, like someone being chased.
(Audience Applauding) I remember a friend told me how when he was eight or nine, a
half naked woman ran to the car window, crying her man was after her with a knife,
but his mother locked the doors and sped away.
Someone tell him his mother was not a coward. That's what he thinks. I tell him it
was because he and his little brother were in the
car, she would not let the troubled world inside.
It was no one's fault.(...) The mind separated from the body. I could almost see
the holes of her eyes, the white fuzz on her tongue, the raised bud soft as a bed
of seeds, the hole of a mouth stretched wide enough to hold a whole baby inside. I
could almost see its eyes at the back of her throat. I
could definitely hear his cries. (Audience Applauding)
All right, so let's see how this thing gonna
work out here. I just read for the rest of my time.
The two books came out last year and I have been,
I tried not to do stuff, so I haven't sent this out, I haven't shown it to anybody,
I just been working on it. And so I was telling Roger like half guzzles, so if you
don't know what the guzzle is, I'm gonna say that just means it's like caught
between my brain and my heart, like caught in my throat. If you do know what the
guzzle is, it's like a half guzzle, which is like some of the rules, like the
refrain that comes through it, and it's what you'd be like I said to myself. And
then maybe said is bouncing around. Don't
worry about it, let's just see what happens.
(Audience Laughing) Sometimes I say to myself, I said to myself, as my mother used
to say in a way that made an echo of the thing she said to herself and me.
Cynthia Ozak said a sentence is a kind of voice with its own suspense, its secret
inner queries, its chants, idiosyncrasies, and soliloquies.
Gil Scott Herron said, I am the closest thing I have to a voice of reason.
I said to the doctor, I am achy, gassy, forgetful, and I pee too much. The doctor
said, that's not illness, Terrence, that's just aging.
If it ain't a disease, why is everybody trying to cure it? I said to myself.
Webster said, epiphora was excessive watering of the eye and also plural for
epistrophe, the repetition of a word at the end of a successive clauses and
sentences. Thelonious Monk figured it out.(...) The park was the first, at first
name, Crystal Lake, the guide said, then for the local star, now after the company
that hired the star, but I never got the name of the park because I said to myself,
the man who behaves as if he will become a statue
in the park dreams of becoming no more than a place.
The sign outside the bathroom said wash your hand. The sign inside the damn
elevator said out of order. I said to my son, it is not only an imperative to wash
your hands, but to exit public bathrooms without touching any faucets or handles
that may have been handled by those who did not wash their hands.
Somewhere Basquiat said, we decided the bullet must have been going very fast.(...)
What concerns me is the enemy we face does not care about wrong or right. They only
care about winning or losing, I said to you. When the Sufi said dance was the best
way to speak with God, I decided to dance a little bit every day.
Thelonious Monk said, the genius is the one who is most himself.
Samuel Johnson said, a man of genius has seldom been ruined by himself.
Nietzsche said, talking about oneself is also a means of concealing oneself.
Defending Kenneth Coke, Frank O'Hara said, not the least function of poetry is to
make vivid our sense of the meaning of words.(...)
Sometimes her bling is backwards, I think somebody said.
I want to turn Rothko's canvases on their side so his doorways become landscapes, I
said to myself.(...) I think knowing Mark Rothko killed
himself colors how you see the paintings, I said to you.
There's just no way to know who in the room can
actually sing before the singing starts, I said to myself.
Gil Scott Herron said, no matter how far wrong you've gone, you can always turn
round.(...) A bird flies in two directions at once, I
said to myself, toward the center and toward the border.
That it said, Lucille Clifton was born with an extra finger, means something, I
said to myself.(...) Every day you are a prisoner trying to master time.(...) The
signs in the park said, free healing, free fortune telling, free Palestine.
He said, the cops said to put my hands up after I was in handcuffs. She said, the
police said to put my hands up after I was in handcuffs. They said, the pigs said
to put my hands up after I was in handcuffs.
Tried and true strategies of fortitude for the self and family in the quadrants of
emotional, spiritual, social and creative life, the name of Hamlet's dog, the
Elizabeth's passion is for lust. My son is Paul Celan, my daughter of the flower of
reason and mystery. I said I would study their subjectivities myself.(...) A
wounded heart can become infected, if not allowed to heal.(...) My mother said, the
first grade of teacher said, the class should call her dumb door for the rest of
the year because of something she said, because of something she said, but she
doesn't remember telling me because she said it to herself.
The people pushing along the sidewalk with no
regard for others are terrible dancers, I said to myself.
She should have said the candidates' actual only campaign platform was white
supremacy, I said to you. The power, power requires
to sustain power is always trouble, I said to myself.
Peter Sellers said he had a violent
aversion to the colors purple and green as true.
Nina Simone said, birds flying high, you know how I feel, and I said I'm feeling.
(...) Nina Simone said, sun in the sky, you know how I feel, and I said I'm feeling.
(...) Use two ears, I said to myself, because one must listen for both the perceived
truth and the actual truth. The perceived is for that which can seem for a period
of time, a moment, a spell, a stretch of so true, or the actual truth can take a
time to tell to be true.(...) Go to the place you would like to be planted,
carrying a shovel and a satchel holding all the seeds of all the fruit you have
eaten in your life, I said to no one. You will receive further instructions from
the other side of the path after I've had my run in with the darkness. The family
can be torn apart in the dark, I said to myself.
Ginsburg said, William Carlos Williams said, we have all sold ourselves out for
heaven as if this earth was excrement shat down from the sky.
You can't embrace God, show you embrace yourself, you said without saying, God put
you here to be witness, I said.(...) You know it's addiction because you can't
understand why other people don't do it, I said to you. You know other people don't
do it, but you can't understand why they don't do it, I said to myself.(...) We
grow learning to accept our parents, to accept ourselves, I should have said to my
son.(...) The black people who have video for family archives and those who have
boxes of photos are luckier than the black people like my people who have almost
nothing to show for our past, I said to myself.(...) On this day in history, my
grandmother, who became a grandmother before 40, and has been single all of her 89
years, having never lived alone until now, said again, it is glad to be alive.
The driver, it is good to be alive. The driver said he'd been given a 911 vision on
an island mountain, but he didn't understand it until after it happened. Other
people said the same thing, I said to myself.(...) An aneurysm of the heart, my
brother said, describing a heart attack or break. An aneurysm of the heart, I said
to myself.(...) When someone asked if I ever imagined a whole war set in motion by
something like that, I said no. But I said to myself, no, I had not considered the
best path from the woods to the blood of the one or two cows and horses in the
field. After their throats are cut for silence and measure, I refuse to make a
monster of myself creeping into the home of the enemy or villain, the loved ones
uncloaked in moonlight, the sad y'all or the last one to live, the most rotten and
thus worthy of suffering, the sadness one lives after that. I did not imagine that.
The children complained they did not ask to be born into
this terrible world, but that's true of every animal ever born.
Where a canary in a mine is a sign of trouble, a crow dragging another crow from
the road as I have witnessed is a sign there is mercy in the world.(...) Where a
crow in the bar is a sign a door or window is open or that the crow has followed
you from the cemetery, a crow in the barn is a sign of nothing. An owl in the barn
is a sign ghosts are watching. The signs say, stay back. The sign said, detour.
Everyone said they heard of the warnings.
James Joyce said an object immensely regarded may be a gate to the access to the
incorruptible eon of the gods.(...) One who has become all eyes does not see, as
Martin said.(...) Flannery O'Connor said, someone said, Flaubert said, it takes at
least three activated sensuous strokes to make an object real.
Where some students find the artificial nigger by Flannery O'Connor explores the
irreducible nonlinear transfusions of confusion for white folks perpetually lost
and colored people frozen like lawn jockeys in New America.(...) Some students find
it's clear evidence of Flannery O'Connor's racism
because her title implies she can identify a real nigger.
A body that refuses to listen to itself quickly becomes trouble, I said to myself.
(...) Gil Scott Herron said, turn around, turn around, turn around. You may come
full circle and be new here again. (...) Power is like a drug that only fills you
with the desire for the drug, I told you. No one said those juvenile years, the
adult inside the parent is disliked or even despised by the child. The adult comes
to understand what it means to be judged unworthy by someone you care for.(...) No
one said those years are also the years you must come to terms with being the
master, the role of Lord and enforcer governing a self, both like and other than
yourself.(...) The comedian said, after neurosis, said a neurosis is when someone
has a fear of no control, making them neurotic, while a psychosis is when someone
has an illusion of total control making them
psychotic. I think optimism is a kind of psychosis.
The officer said, do you know how fast you were going? Along the interstate of my
home state in South Carolina, the people who stayed said after flames were thrown
on their fields and the shacks in those fields and the bodies in the shacks,
everything in the field, a flame became ash, which when muddled with rain and mud
and time renewed the field and the scene of the crime, I said to myself. My son
kept it himself the year he lived with me. Everything inside him was burning until
he was blushing unwillingly without speaking, expressing himself. One of the hueses
said the word tattooed wall to wall on the inside of the skull is horizon.
Every honest statement is a state against entropy. Each false statement accelerates
our journey to the end of the world, I said to myself. In that other life, I'm a
celloist by day and a jazz basis by night, my saddle of bows like arrows and my
instrument like a giant wooden sculpture of a big mouth bass pivoting on a spear. I
survived to sing what I say to myself. (...) Where some do not grasp what's special
in Nina Simone until suffering a little bit of living, I did not until a thorough
heartbreak fully appreciate Tammy Chorale.
Wisdom requires submission to that which is greater than power.(...) The guy said
van Gogh-- we're almost here. The guy said van Gogh's mother, like the typical
Dutch mother, was obsessed with cleaning and the purity of the soul.
If we can agree how inexplicable it is to be alive, can we agree how desperately
one simply wants to know what happens after death? You know and I know something
wholly otherworldly dwells at the periphery of everything, only you are afraid to
call it anything less than religion, where I'm afraid
to call it anything but something no one could name.
I want to show you what it's all about over again, I said to you. A heart that is
partly turtle, partly tortoise, housed in an emerald shell, a mind that is partly
goldfish, partly shellfish, wrapped in water, wrapped in glass. What didn't happen
can still be true, I said to you. She said she stole just $1 to test the scale of
retribution.(...) When Chomsky said slavery is now regarded as reprehensible
because the people in power have become more tolerant, I said to myself, it's
because the people in power realize the cost to keep enslaved and slave was
unsustainable. They were equally immoral motherfuckers who realized slavery was bad
business.(...) I said to my son, pigeons are essentially rats with wings, which
makes them worse than rats because they're flying rats.
Once they were a person who looked like you and me and at various parts of the day
thought the same things as us, but after many fussy hustling, sis-a-fussy-ing
hours, pushing and dragging and being stoned by the big jagged rocks of life became
someone both like you and other than you and myself.(...) When the path turned to
stones, I found the rock. When the rock cracked open, I found an egg. When the egg
broke, I found a tiny emerald turtle. When the turtle began to grow, I sharpened
half the rock against the stone. When I sharpened the rock, sparks splintered into
flame. When the flame was high and the turtle the size of
an emerald helmet, a crown with a sunroof, I roped myself.
Down with gravity, I tell the version of myself that heads to the bathroom to weep
and to stall at the movies. Brother, don't run, I said to the screen. If they're
going to shoot you anyway, make them look you in the face. The sign said caution,
wet floor, danger. The sign said free Palestine. The sign suggested things people
said were signs. Someone said, I notice all the portraits of truly great writers,
the mouth is always closed. Somewhere Rilke said religion is art to those who have
no creativity. God is the most ancient work of art. Still, I hope in time we'll
meet again, said Beverly Glenn Copeland, who I thought for many years was a woman
with the goatee and then briefly a man in transition. And I now know to be an
uncategorical musician. Still in time, I hope we'll meet again. The menu said it
was chicken, but I'm telling you, that ain't taste like no chicken.
You don't want to have to do it. You have to want to do it, I said to myself.
Frank Stanford said, Francis said, both his hands were black as two boots worn in a
Bible flood. When he blacked out, he laughed like a crack milk bottle, like the
drowned black music kicking around in the mouth of a whale and river, like the
three spells the midwife cast over the sleeping child, the teenage parents, and the
dog who does not speak but barked with tribal accent.
Someone said, why bother with mirrors in glass houses?
It's best to be a minor guard with eyes in the back of your head and eyeglasses pop
as if trying to give your mind a view of heaven. That's
how Patricia always wear her glasses, I said to myself.
There are people who have said, I don't know what I would have done had I not been
for this or that, but no one knows where they'd be if they had not done what they
did not do to get here or where they are. Having exposed my hunger, I covered my
plate after every meal as if it was the scene of a crime, because in my childhood,
desiring food was a sign of neediness, I should have said to you. The practice of
drawing is self-actualization exercise, I said to myself. One sees something in the
mind and attempts to put a representation of that vision
in the world. My son said I talked to him like a professor.
I'll be your father regardless of our bond, I said to my son. You have seen where
I'm from, I said to my son another time. Boy, I will fuck you up.
I asked myself why I said it after that.
Nostalgia, Homer Simpson said, everything we loved
about the past except for how it got us to the present.
Someone said things simply have the virtue of having never been done.(...) We are
on a journey to find happiness inside and outside our families. In the meantime, we
pass the time making stuff, I said to my son. I just don't want you to be anybody's
slave, I said to him. You must learn to be
your own mother and father, I said to myself.
(Applause)
Thank you.
All right now.
Coming up next.
Also someone who just always feels like family. She just always feels like somebody
I grew up with, could have grown up with, and maybe did grow up with, and she was
just, I don't know, Evie Shockley. She knows all the words. Come on, Evie.
(Applause) Oh my gosh.
OK, that doesn't make it easier to follow him.
Terrence, thanks for that beautiful reading.
Thank you all, thank you Lauren, thank you Joanne.
Poetry lovers, let's do this thing.
I have a few things I want to do.
I was inspired by some of the readings over the course of these three days
to share an elegy that I wrote, because I love the way that people's names are
being brought into the room. So that's where I'm going to start.
How long has this Jane been gone?
Not long, not long. In fact, she's back, flapping with the gale force laughter of
the first kites of March, growling like a motorcycle of liberation,(...) howling
like the angel of field hollers at the bleachers of poetic apathy, where they're
always ready to make some noise but never get in the game. Oh yes, she's back. Back
like she was never gone. Still blues washing over the whitewashing of the music.
Still pinning the tail on the covert donkey of domination.
Still hissing wisdom into the imperial bath water.(...) Still cussing the fuck out
of evil rapist punks and the friendly ones too.
She's right beneath your mama's left breast, right up in the cook-footed cornbread.
Still breaking out like sweat on the drummer's forehead.
(...) Still chuckling in the backyard over her hot diaspora stew.
Can't you hear her? Rumbling like an
earthquake through the crowded blocks of watts.
Sizzling like the wind off the ancient coast of Ghana. Honking like the traffic
symphony in the hot sauce streets of New York.
Sizzling onto the untamed sands of the people's beaches of Cuba. How long has this
Jane, this breathtaking Jane Cortez been gone? Not long. Not long. In fact, she's
back. Yeah, back for seconds. A little more Armstrong funk in the sunshine. Another
helping of that spicy Caesarean callaloo with a bitter red pepper poet mixed in.
Another round of big mama Thornton blues brew, right Bumblebee?(...) Yeah, she's
looking for a second slice of that wicked shit gee in cooked up.(...) Another bite
of that African truth casserole, Chana Pozo serving from his conga. Very fine, very
fine.(...) One more taste of the scatology spittle Ella still slinging around the
Savoy ballroom. One more ride on V train this side
of time before she takes it to her final destination.
Have you seen her?(...) Drinking the conjure woman's pot liquor straight out of the
pot.(...) Sashaying across the evening sky like a bouquet of black girl smiles.
Have you heard her?
Toxic in her gut bucket lullabies into the ears of desperate children, exhausted
men, and outraged women.(...) Sweeping the dust of corporate sponsored exploitation
off the bandstand with her fire spitting lyrical jazz cleanup crew.
Have you felt her? Rattling your bones with the daily news of the latest pro
democracy drone strike. Licking with sandpaper cat tongue kisses the numb shell of
cultural desensitization to violence we call
paying the bills. Have you seen her? Have you seen her?
How long, how long has our Jane been gone?
Not long, not long. She's no farther away than the sound of her name and her
hellified poetry ringing out of our long memory
throats. If we act right, she'll be right back.
That's just me trying to channel one of my champions, one of my heroes.(...) And if
you don't know, please go find out.(...) Jane Cortez.
I'm going to continue calling out some of my sister artists
and inspirations and, you know, companions on this journey.
The amazing artist, Alison Saar.
Yes. Give it up for Alison.
Yes.
She designed, she sculpted this beautiful piece of work that Grace is the cover of
Suddenly We.(...) And she calls the sculpture which she makes, you know, she works
a lot with found materials and you can kind of imagine what she found by looking at
this. But you might not be able to see what she named the
sculpture from. It's called, the piece is called Bluebird.
My poem is called Perched.
I am black, comely,(...) a girl on the cusp of desire.
My dangling toes take the rest, the rest of my body refuses.
Spine upright, my pose proposes anticipation.
I poise in copper colored tension, intent on
manifesting my soul in the discouraging world.
Under the rough eyes of others, I stiffen.
If I must be hard, it will be as a tree, alive with change.
Inside me, a love of beauty rises like sap,
sprouts from my scalp and stretches forth.
I send out my song, an aria blue and feathered
and grow toward it, choirs bare but soon to bud.
I am black and becoming.
( Applause )
I don't think she's still here or maybe she is.(...) This
next poem has an epigraph from the beloved Nikki Finney.
I am reading this poem as a representative of the childless cat ladies.
Nikki, oh,(...) I'm here. We're here.
Nikki, I love this line. She says, the things that I give birth to matter.
The things that I give birth to give birth to other things.
The blessings.
I gave mine away. Not all but the greater portion, some would say. I gave away the
ready claim to goodness, to purpose. I gave away Mary,(...) Sarah and Isis. I gave
away necessity and invention.(...) I gave away a whole holiday but I kept Billy.
I gave away the chance to try and fail to have it all.
(...) I gave away the one thing that makes some men pay.
I gave away the pedestal, the bouquet.(...) I
gave away Nell Wright but I kept Sula Peace.
I gave away the fine tooth comb but I kept the oyster knife.
I gave away the first word the new mouth forms,
the easiest to parlay across so many languages.
Escaping the maw, I gave away the power to hold and be held in sway. But I kept
Cho, Parton, Finney, Chapman and Tomei. I gave away the Eve who left the garden
that day but kept the cool green shady fruitless
fruitful stay.(...) The evening that did not fall away.
(Applause) I think I want to go to one new piece. This is nerve wracking.
Where did it go?
Oh, here it is. Okay.
I get to do one more shout out to a poet who means a lot to me.
I think the only thing I'm going to try to say to prepare you for what you're going
to hear is just that I think about language and there's
this phrase, do people still say it? In the nick of time.
I was like, what the heck is the nick of time? And then I started thinking about
the word nick and the word time and just the concept.
So here we go. This poem is called "Time, the Nick."
And the epigraph is from Dion Brand.
She says, what is in time?
Everything and nothing.
The ambulance,(...) the apology, (...) the wrinkle,(...) the retrieval.
Catastrophe averted is still carried in the
bloodstream,(...) constricted heart, arteries,
cell folds of what could have been collected and held out to community, posterity.
The chasing hounds, their toothy, growling fury, even
escaped, bites the imagination, descended from danger.
Nips and holds the skin of the then to the
now, a bloody fold pinned by an ivory clip.
The nick of time. A mark born and reborn, generation after generation.
The time nipped, hours, days, years spent holding the line against deaths
designated, designed, waiting for us. The nick marking the passage of the time of
unfreedom on our bodies.(...) Passed down as the babies passed through the nick of
time, opening, bloody, between slick thighs.
The rebirth of hope, of will,(...) children stapled by bomb shards to their
people's past, some far too late future branded as just in time, are nicked,
un-nicked into a world where they must steal back what belongs to them.
Everything and nothing.(...) The arrival,(...) the
acknowledgment,(...) the reparations,(...) the return.
( Applause )
I'm going to just read two more.(...) This one I'm going back to read an old one
just because it doesn't actually shout out Harriet Mullen, but you know I'm going
to shout out Harriet Mullen. So I would call this the first poem I wrote under the
influence of Harriet. (...) She's a drug. She's addictive.
This is called "You Must Walk This Lonesome."
Say hello to moon, leads you into trees as thick as folk on Easter pews. Dark but
ventured through, amazing was blind but now fireflies glittering dangling from
evergreens like Christmas oracles. Soon you meet the riverbank, down by the
riverside. Water baptizes your feet, moon bursts back in. Low, yellow, swing low,
sweet chariot of cheese shines on in the river. Cup hands and sit, but never saw
inside a peace be still. Mix in your tears, moon distills distress like yours so
nobody knows the trouble it causes. Pull up a log and sit until your empty is full,
your straight is wool, your death is you. The moonshine will do that. Barter with
you. What you got for what you need. Draw from the river like it is well with my
soul. Oh moon, you croon, and home you go.
And I'm going to read one more and sit down.
This poem is the final poem and suddenly we, it
is a poem that I hope to not have to read someday.
There's a dedication you might say, "Poulet du mille plus, s'it m'emorial du camp
de mille," which just means for the 2,000 and more who were held in the s'it
m'emorial, the memorial site of the camp in Les Mille. Les Mille is a city, a town
in the south of France, and it also means the thousands.
Les Mille.(...) There is no poem unless I,
(...) we,(...) can find the courage to speak.
In the middle of a vacation in the south of France,(...) a chance to visit a World
War II detention center arises,(...) dusty and bleak, just
outside, just past the scent of lavender in an ancient heat.
The first thing you see and the last thing you visit is a boxcar.
You know what it means.
It takes the same toll on the breath, the pulse, as
the rusted shackles displayed in another damned museum.
There are histories of torture preserved all around us, formally, officially, with
placards and institutional funding, (...) casually,(...) quietly, unavoidably, in
the quality of a glance, the poverty of an existence,
(...) the demographics of a mall, a church, a prison.
In a former tile factory,(...) we learn again how
anything can be misused, how anyone can be abused.
A kiln is not a dormitory until it is.
There,(...) here, slept people who were too Jewish to be German, too German to be
French, too despised and feared to be defended, even by
those who feared they, we,(...) might soon be despised.
If I now say Palestine, have I forgotten Auschwitz?
If I say settlements, have I now forgotten camps?
If I don't say Palestine,(...) have I
forgotten Elmina,(...) Selma,(...) Cape Town, Haiti?
Must every place name on earth be a shorthand for violence on a map of grief?
Dominican Republic,(...) Hiroshima, (...) Sriburne, Rwanda,(...) Cambodia,(...)
Ankara,(...) Adana, (...) Odessa,(...) Nanking,
yesterday and yesterday's yesterday, the planet pushing up sycamores and lavender,
rice and plantains, fertilized with lead and blood, with rain
from poisonous clouds and the dust that becomes of the dead.

wishing they hadn't come. If only we'd stayed home listening to the phone ring and
ring and not picking up. We could just keep staring out of our own jails into an
unbending dark wallowing in blue waiting for our sons to rise.
